articles.headline: Behind League of Legends, E-Sports’s Main Attraction
articles.snippet: Riot Games, creator of the wildly popular League of Legends, says it puts players’ enjoyment above the need to produce profits. And that may be the key to the game’s success.
articles.abstract: Riot Games, creator of the wildly popular League of Legends, says it puts players’ enjoyment above the need to produce profits. And that may be the key to the game’s success.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the company behind one of the world’s most popular video games, League of Legends, started organizing tournaments — noisy events where professional players compete under huge screens in arenas packed with fans — it had to design a championship trophy. That proved trickier than it sounds. A trophy should be grand and gleaming — that much seemed obvious. But nobody at Riot Games, which owns League of Legends, focused on a pretty basic question: How much should the trophy weigh?

articles.headline: Secret Money Fueling a Flood of Political Ads
articles.snippet: More than half of the general election advertising aired by outside groups in the battle for control of Congress has come from organizations that disclose little or nothing about their donors.
articles.abstract: More than half of the general election advertising aired by outside groups in the battle for control of Congress has come from organizations that disclose little or nothing about their donors.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than half of the general election advertising aired by outside groups in the battle for control of Congress has come from organizations that disclose little or nothing about their donors, a flood of secret money that is now at the center of a debate over the line between free speech and corruption.

articles.headline: The Most Serious Threat When Using Credit: You
articles.snippet: Even researchers of the psychology of credit card use admit they don’t always use cash or debit cards.
articles.abstract: Even researchers of the psychology of credit card use admit they don’t always use cash or debit cards.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was hard not to feel helpless this week after the news that the president himself sought weekly briefings this summer about the cyberattacks against JPMorgan Chase and other financial services companies. Who was it? What did they want? Nobody knew.

articles.headline: ‘Putin’s Tiger,’ in a Territory Grab All His Own, Swims to China
articles.snippet: A Siberian tiger released into the wild in Russia in the spring crossed a river this week into China, where wildlife officials are tracking his whereabouts.
articles.abstract: A Siberian tiger released into the wild in Russia in the spring crossed a river this week into China, where wildlife officials are tracking his whereabouts.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Virile, canny and possessed with a boundless appetite for red meat, Kuzya, a 23-month-old Siberian tiger, would seem the perfect mascot for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, who had a personal hand in reintroducing Kuzya to the wild in the Russian Far East in May.

articles.headline: Wall Street’s Whipsaw Week Shows Global Economy’s Flaws
articles.snippet: With markets priced for expectations of a steadily improving global economy, there are troubling signs that growth may have stalled.
articles.abstract: With markets priced for expectations of a steadily improving global economy, there are troubling signs that growth may have stalled.
articles.lead_paragraph: Financial markets have been priced for perfection. And this week, the world economy looked far from perfect.
articles.byline: By Neil Irwin and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: TV Ratings by Nielsen Had Errors for Months
articles.snippet: The mistake raises questions about the company’s increasingly criticized system for measuring TV audiences.
articles.abstract: The mistake raises questions about the company’s increasingly criticized system for measuring TV audiences.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nielsen, the television research firm, acknowledged on Friday that it had been reporting inaccurate ratings for the broadcast networks for the last seven months, a mistake that raises questions about the company’s increasingly criticized system for measuring TV audiences.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Emily Steel

articles.headline: In Lending Circles, a Roundabout Way to a Higher Credit Score
articles.snippet: Lending circles — groups of people who lend money to one another at no interest — are seen as a promising tool to help low-income Americans build their credit records.
articles.abstract: Lending circles — groups of people who lend money to one another at no interest — are seen as a promising tool to help low-income Americans build their credit records.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shweta Kohli has always paid her own way. Her straight-A average won her a full scholarship to San Francisco State University at the same time she worked a 40-hour week as a waitress at a cafe. But when she applied for a credit card after graduation, she was turned down because she had no credit history.

articles.headline: Officials Admit a ‘Defeat’ by Ebola in Sierra Leone
articles.snippet: The decision to help families treat patients at home signifies a significant shift in the struggle against the rampaging disease.
articles.abstract: The decision to help families treat patients at home signifies a significant shift in the struggle against the rampaging disease.
articles.lead_paragraph: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — Acknowledging a major “defeat” in the fight against Ebola, international health officials battling the epidemic in Sierra Leone approved plans on Friday to help families tend to patients at home, recognizing that they are overwhelmed and have little chance of getting enough treatment beds in place quickly to meet the surging need.

articles.headline: As Apprentices in Classroom, Teachers Learn What Works
articles.snippet: A charter school training program reflects the belief that teachers, like doctors, need to practice repeatedly with experienced supervisors before they can take the reins in classes of their own.
articles.abstract: A charter school training program reflects the belief that teachers, like doctors, need to practice repeatedly with experienced supervisors before they can take the reins in classes of their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Monica DeSantiago wondered how in the world she would get the students to respect her.

articles.headline: No Smoke, No Mirrors: The Dutch Pension Plan
articles.snippet: In the Netherlands, a system rests on the idea that each generation should pay its own costs — and that those costs must be measured accurately.
articles.abstract: In the Netherlands, a system rests on the idea that each generation should pay its own costs — and that those costs must be measured accurately.
articles.lead_paragraph: Imagine a place where pensions were not an ever-deepening quagmire, where the numbers told the whole story and where workers could count on a decent retirement.

articles.headline: Campaigns Find Ad Space Finite, Even on the Web
articles.snippet: As digital advertising matures, with more sophisticated targeting and an expanding definition of a viewer, campaigns and outside groups are finding that premium space has long been booked.
articles.abstract: As digital advertising matures, with more sophisticated targeting and an expanding definition of a viewer, campaigns and outside groups are finding that premium space has long been booked.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It turns out that the Internet does not have infinite capacity. At least not for political ads.

articles.headline: At Forlorn Urban Churches, Mass Gets Crowded in a Flash
articles.snippet: The latest trend in Rust Belt Catholicism, the Mass mob, is bringing thousands of suburban Catholics to visit the struggling urban churches of their parents and grandparents.
articles.abstract: The latest trend in Rust Belt Catholicism, the Mass mob, is bringing thousands of suburban Catholics to visit the struggling urban churches of their parents and grandparents.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The glory days of Holy Ghost Church were years ago, when Catholics packed into the wooden pews, beneath a starry barrel-vaulted ceiling, listening to bells and kissing icons as priests in colorful robes intoned in ancient tongues the liturgies of a faraway land.

articles.headline: Amid Ebola Crisis, Liberian Army Sees Its Chance at Rebranding
articles.snippet: The Liberian Army, working alongside American troops, has become a linchpin in the fight against the Ebola virus. But it faces a wary public.
articles.abstract: The Liberian Army, working alongside American troops, has become a linchpin in the fight against the Ebola virus. But it faces a wary public.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — For decades, Liberians have referred to the Armed Forces of Liberia as “soldiers them.”

articles.headline: 2nd Ebola Case in U.S. Stokes Fears of Health Care Workers
articles.snippet: Officials were trying to figure out how a nurse who had treated Thomas Eric Duncan became infected despite wearing protective gear, as news of the new infection stoked the fears of health care workers across the country.
articles.abstract: Officials were trying to figure out how a nurse who had treated Thomas Eric Duncan became infected despite wearing protective gear, as news of the new infection stoked the fears of health care workers across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — A nurse here became the first person to contract Ebola within the United States, prompting local, state and federal officials who had settled into a choreographed response to scramble on Sunday to solve the mystery of how she became infected, despite wearing protective gear, and to monitor additional people possibly at risk.

articles.headline: Canadian Pacific Railway Makes Deal Overture to CSX
articles.snippet: CSX has been cool to the idea of a transaction, which would create a company worth more than $60 billion, people briefed on the matter said.
articles.abstract: CSX has been cool to the idea of a transaction, which would create a company worth more than $60 billion, people briefed on the matter said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Canadian Pacific Railway recently approached CSX, the big Florida-based rail line, about a merger that would create a company worth more than $60 billion, people briefed on the matter said on Sunday.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: YouTube Takes Manhattan
articles.snippet: A studio that YouTube is opening in Manhattan will bring the company in proximity to more traditional creators of media content, along with a huge new pool of talent.
articles.abstract: A studio that YouTube is opening in Manhattan will bring the company in proximity to more traditional creators of media content, along with a huge new pool of talent.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, Zayna Aston, a communications executive at Google, met me at the company’s offices in Manhattan to show me around YouTube Space New York, the newest version of the production facilities the company has already opened in London, Los Angeles and Tokyo over the last two years.

articles.headline: Leaning Forward, MSNBC Loses Ground to Rival CNN
articles.snippet: Audiences have thinned for all cable television news, but the opinionated MSNBC has suffered as CNN has grabbed more of its terrain with a surge in international news.
articles.abstract: Audiences have thinned for all cable television news, but the opinionated MSNBC has suffered as CNN has grabbed more of its terrain with a surge in international news.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rachel Maddow, the biggest star on the MSNBC cable network, just posted her lowest quarterly ratings results ever.

articles.headline: It’s Alive! And It Grows Into a Jack-o’-Lantern
articles.snippet: With the strangely shaped “pumpkinstein,” a California farmer found a way to carve himself a piece of the $7 billion in business Halloween now generates.
articles.abstract: With the strangely shaped “pumpkinstein,” a California farmer found a way to carve himself a piece of the $7 billion in business Halloween now generates.
articles.lead_paragraph: FILLMORE, Calif. — Like Victor Frankenstein, Tony Dighera was determined to bring a new creature to life. Though he was fairly new to farming, Mr. Dighera saw profit to be made in strangely shaped pumpkins.

articles.headline: Venture Capitalists Return to Backing Science Start-Ups
articles.snippet: Start-ups that make fusion reactors, natural pesticides and tiny rocket engines have the attention of venture capitalists, but profit is still a must.
articles.abstract: Start-ups that make fusion reactors, natural pesticides and tiny rocket engines have the attention of venture capitalists, but profit is still a must.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vestaron makes an eco-friendly pesticide derived from spider venom. Bagaveev uses 3-D printers to make rocket engines for nanosatellites. Transatomic Power is developing a next-generation reactor that runs on nuclear waste.

articles.headline: For Infected Nurse’s Neighbors, Ebola Brings Worry to Doorstep
articles.snippet: On Sunday, for the second time in two weeks, Ebola transformed part of Dallas into a scene of concern and contamination, with another day of uneasy questions.
articles.abstract: On Sunday, for the second time in two weeks, Ebola transformed part of Dallas into a scene of concern and contamination, with another day of uneasy questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Carleen and Ed Guerrero were asleep when two police officers rapped on their door at 5 a.m. on Sunday to tell them that the Ebola virus had come to their leafy neighborhood just north of downtown.

articles.headline: Highway Guardrail May Be Deadly, States Say
articles.snippet: A federal lawsuit claims that despite assurances from the manufacturer and the Federal Highway Administration, guardrails installed along highways do not function properly and could kill or injure motorists during crashes.
articles.abstract: A federal lawsuit claims that despite assurances from the manufacturer and the Federal Highway Administration, guardrails installed along highways do not function properly and could kill or injure motorists during crashes.
articles.lead_paragraph: By last month, state transportation officials in Missouri said they had seen enough.
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory and Aaron M. Kessler

articles.headline: G.O.P. Right Still Has Doubt About Christie
articles.snippet: As Gov. Chris Christie lays the groundwork for a Republican presidential run, the distrust that he faces from social and religious conservatives may be the biggest and least understood obstacle.
articles.abstract: As Gov. Chris Christie lays the groundwork for a Republican presidential run, the distrust that he faces from social and religious conservatives may be the biggest and least understood obstacle.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a confidential meeting over the summer, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey boasted to influential evangelical leaders that he was the state’s “first pro-life governor since Roe vs. Wade,” reminded them that he had vetoed legislation allowing gays to wed and, in a knowing reference to the Gospel of Matthew, spoke of his moral obligation to help the “least of us.”

articles.headline: Jean Tirole Wins Nobel in Economics for Work on Regulation
articles.snippet: Mr. Tirole, a French economist, has provided insight into how governments can best tame powerful firms, the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences said.
articles.abstract: Mr. Tirole, a French economist, has provided insight into how governments can best tame powerful firms, the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The French economist Jean Tirole, a student of imperfect markets, has spent decades dissecting the many industries where competition does not fulfill the textbook promise that prices will be low and quality will be high.

articles.headline: C.D.C. Rethinking Methods to Stop Spread of Ebola
articles.snippet: The transmission of the virus to a nurse in Dallas forced the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to study how health officials perform infection control at hospitals.
articles.abstract: The transmission of the virus to a nurse in Dallas forced the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to study how health officials perform infection control at hospitals.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The transmission of the Ebola virus to a nurse here forced the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Monday to reconsider its approach to containing the disease, with state and federal officials re-examining whether equipment and procedures were adequate or too loosely followed, and whether more decontamination steps are necessary when health workers leave isolation units.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez, Sabrina Tavernise and Richard Fausset
